user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_http_version:
```c
static bool
parse_http_version (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    const char *http_string,
                    size_t len)
{
  const char *const h = http_string; /**< short alias */
  mhd_assert (NULL != http_string);

  /* String must start with 'HTTP/d.d', case-sensetive match.
   * See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9112#name-http-version */
  if ((HTTP_VER_LEN != len) ||
      ('H' != h[0]) || ('T' != h[1]) || ('T' != h[2]) || ('P' != h[3]) ||
      ('/' != h[4])
      || ('.' != h[6]) ||
      (('0' > h[5]) || ('9' < h[5])) ||
      (('0' > h[7]) || ('9' < h[7])))
  {
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_INVALID;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                    REQUEST_MALFORMED);
    return false;
  }
  if (1 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* HTTP/1.x */
    if (1 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_1;
    else if (0 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_0;
    else
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_2__1_9;

    return true;
  }

  if (0 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* Too old major version */
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_TOO_OLD;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                    REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_TOO_OLD);
    return false;
  }

  connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_FUTURE;
  transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                  REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_NOT_SUPPORTED);
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                  REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_NOT_SUPPORTED);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls a different function (transmit_error_response_static). There is no evidence in the provided code that parse_http_version calls itself directly, nor that transmit_error_response_static (or any function it calls) invokes parse_http_version. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated. (It would be violated only if transmit_error_response_static or another called function eventually calls parse_http_version, creating indirect recursion.)
